If you’re not fully vaccinated, you’ll need to show proof of a negative PCR test (taken no more than 72 hours before entry) when entering Belarus. Foreign arrivals below the age of 6 are exempt from this requirement. This requirement does not apply to holders of permanent or temporary residency in Belarus.

International Restrictions:
*All travellers: There are no COVID-19 related travel restrictions for Belarus. There are no restrictions for foreign national to enter and leave Belarus, including through a land border, with exception of the Russia /Belarus state border (see above). If you plan to enter or exit Belarus by land, check the travel advice of the relevant neighbouring country, as coronavirus-related restrictions may be put in place at short notice.
Some flights continue to operate out of Minsk and regional airports, although at present there are no direct flights to destinations in western Europe.
You’ll need to have valid medical insurance before travelling to Belarus. You’ll be asked to provide proof of your insurance when you apply for your visa or on arrival at Minsk, Brest, Vitebsk, Gomel, Grodno and Mogilev airports under the 30 day visa-free regime. Contact the Embassy of the Republic of Belarus in your country for full details of what’s required.
*COVID-19: All COVID restrictions for international travellers entering Belarus have been lifted. There is no longer a mandatory requirement to provide proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test result to enter the country, regardless of your COVID-19 vaccination status.
If you’re planning on travelling by rail, you should contact your train or tour operator to seek their advice. You should also consider contacting your nearest Russian Embassy for advice on the latest situation for rail travellers.


Internal restrictions:
*Travel, accommodation, public places and services in Belarus: There are no current coronavirus restrictions for travel or accommodation in Belarus.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
